snippet.textDisplay: I only wish I had been introduced to Critical Role so much earlier. I’ve laughed and cried with the episodes I’ve seen so far and I am so looking forward to watching the animated series even as I try to go through the rest of the other videos. And yeah, prime’s getting my subscription because of this. Thank you, all of you, Team Critical Role! You made my days so much better!

snippet.textDisplay: While I'm super excited for the vox machina animated series The line "no one has ever tried to adapt an rpg campaign into an animated series" is actually kinda false. Arslen and record of lodos war were animated based on rpg campaigns. And there are other animated series that were also based on rpg campaigns. So it's not exactly breaking new grounds. Though in the sense of adapting a live campaign that people have been watching for a long while now then that line makes more sense. But regardless i do think it'll be absolutely awesome!
snippet.textOriginal: While I'm super excited for the vox machina animated series The line "no one has ever tried to adapt an rpg campaign into an animated series" is actually kinda false. Arslen and record of lodos war were animated based on rpg campaigns. And there are other animated series that were also based on rpg campaigns. So it's not exactly breaking new grounds. Though in the sense of adapting a live campaign that people have been watching for a long while now then that line makes more sense. But regardless i do think it'll be absolutely awesome!

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, I've got to ask: Seeing as how this is an adaptation of an RPG, that at times either used content from the official Dungeons and Dragons game, or similar rules sets, like Pathfinder: How much will have to be changed to remove 'Copyrighted Intellectual Property"?
I admit, I'm one of those late to arrive to Critical Role, so I haven't watched many episodes in full; I have no idea how close they kept to the rules/critters/classes from the various sets (although in one of the 'anime trailers', one of the characters was using a gun, which looked like he may have been playing the 'Gunslinger' class from Pathfinder ^_^).
snippet.textOriginal:
Okay, I've got to ask: Seeing as how this is an adaptation of an RPG, that at times either used content from the official Dungeons and Dragons game, or similar rules sets, like Pathfinder:  How much will have to be changed to remove 'Copyrighted Intellectual Property"?
     I admit, I'm one of those late to arrive to Critical Role, so I haven't watched many episodes in full; I have no idea how close they kept to the rules/critters/classes from the various sets (although in one of the 'anime trailers', one of the characters was using a gun, which looked like he may have been playing the 'Gunslinger' class from Pathfinder ^_^).

snippet.textDisplay: Very cool, one caveat about the opening is that this is definitely not the first time a tabletop campaign has been adapted into an animated series though. Check out Record of Lodoss War for a classic example. Super high fantasy serious campaign turned into a series of light novels which was then turned into an anime. A more recent example is Goblin Slayer which is basically if Tucker's Kobolds were its own campaign, except they're goblins instead of kobolds. This one's so rooted in archetypal D&D that its characters are referred to by their class names rather than having actual ones.
snippet.textOriginal: Very cool, one caveat about the opening is that this is definitely not the first time a tabletop campaign has been adapted into an animated series though. Check out Record of Lodoss War for a classic example. Super high fantasy serious campaign turned into a series of light novels which was then turned into an anime. A more recent example is Goblin Slayer which is basically if Tucker's Kobolds were its own campaign, except they're goblins instead of kobolds. This one's so rooted in archetypal D&D that its characters are referred to by their class names rather than having actual ones.

snippet.textDisplay: Record of the Lodoss War is an RPG campaign that was adapted into multiple media forms, including an animated series, and this was thirty years ago.
snippet.textOriginal: Record of the Lodoss War is an RPG campaign that was adapted into multiple media forms, including an animated series, and this was thirty years ago.

0:00 i mean... Record of Lodoss War anyone?

Still, i would say Vox Machina has the chance of becoming what Lodoss was for D&D in Japan in those years, it has all the lore, characters and story to be a hit and hopefully it brings even more people into the world

snippet.textDisplay: I love this I just started watching critical role a few months ago on campaign 1 and I haven’t stopped, I’ve been binge watching and my DM told me about this and my jaw hit the floor. I was like “I would love to see this animated!” He looks at me and says “they actually are starting to animate it.” And I was like O.o “DM say what?” I’m just now in the early 40’s on the episode count and I’m addicted now can’t wait for this, love you Vox Machina May you roll nat 20s all day and make Matt sweat.

snippet.textDisplay: Is anyone else aware that there are actually at least two anime shows in existence that are explicitly based off of tabletop rpgs? (“Slayers” and “Record of Lodoss War” to name the two I know). But no, they’re “breaking new ground”. Don’t get me wrong, super excited for this series, but get your facts straight, you aren’t even close to the first to do this, but hopefully you’re the first to do it really really well!
snippet.textOriginal: Is anyone else aware that there are actually at least two anime shows in existence that are explicitly based off of tabletop rpgs? (“Slayers” and “Record of Lodoss War” to name the two I know). But no, they’re “breaking new ground”. Don’t get me wrong, super excited for this series, but get your facts straight, you aren’t even close to the first to do this, but hopefully you’re the first to do it really really well!

snippet.textDisplay:
"No one has ever really tried to adapt...an RPG campaign into an animated series. So we're actually breaking new ground."

Technically true! The Riddick movies were only very loosely based on Vin Diesel's RPG campaigns, and also weren't animated. :P
snippet.textOriginal:
"No one has ever really tried to adapt...an RPG campaign into an animated series. So we're actually breaking new ground."

Technically true! The Riddick movies were only very loosely based on Vin Diesel's RPG campaigns, and also weren't animated. :P

snippet.textDisplay: Them reading their scripts in their old campaign 1 seats just feels like the knights of the round table returning. There is something mythical and magical about that moment that just beings back all of the memories that made me love dungeons and dragons. This is the show that got me and my friends to all learn dnd and play it together for the past 2 or 3 years. We have played dungeons and dragons every Saturday since. I was in high school when I started and now I have been out for 2 years. This is the one thing that brings me join without fail and I have no regrets what so ever about claiming the nerd title. If having fun is being a nerd then I’m a F***ing Nerd. Thank you to all of you at Critical Role, you are legends.
snippet.textOriginal: Them reading their scripts in their old campaign 1 seats just feels like the knights of the round table returning. There is something mythical and magical about that moment that just beings back all of the memories that made me love dungeons and dragons. This is the show that got me and my friends to all learn dnd and play it together for the past 2 or 3 years. We have played dungeons and dragons every Saturday since. I was in high school when I started and now I have been out for 2 years. This is the one thing that brings me join without fail and I have no regrets what so ever about claiming the nerd title. If having fun is being a nerd then I’m a F***ing Nerd. Thank you to all of you at Critical Role, you are legends.
